questiontext.text:
A force, $$F$$, of 195 N stretches a spring by a distance, $$x$$, of 3.3 cm.




What is the spring constant, $$k$$, in this case?

$$k$$ = {1:NUMERICAL:=-5909.1:-118.1818#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} N/m

How much work would need to be done to stretch this spring by 4 cm, from its unstretched position?

Work = {1:NUMERICAL:=4.7:0.094545#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} J

(Please give your answers correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #1).

generalfeedback.text:
Remember that Hooke's Law states $$F=-k.x$$ for the elastic deformation of a spring:




Therefore:

$$k=-\frac{F}{x}=-5909.1 N/m$$


Work, $$W$$, is defined as the force, $$F$$, applied to a resistance, multiplied by the displacement, $$x$$, of the resistance in the direction of the force:


$$W=F.x$$


When the magnitude of $$F$$ depends on the value of $$x$$, as is the case here, this expression can be modified slightly:

$$W=\int ^x_0F.dx$$

Which in this case is equal to:

$$W=\int ^x_0k.x.dx=\frac{1}{2}.k.x^2=4.7 J$$

(Remember to convert from cm to m in all of the above calculations)

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Image 1 adapted from ' http://demo.webassign.net/ebooks/cj6demo/art/images/ssg/c10/chap10007.gif'

Image 2 adapted from 'http://onlinephys.com/hooke7.gif'

hint.text:
HINT

Apply Hooke's Law to answer the first part of the question.

Then integrate the force over the distance over which it is applied to answer the second part of the question.

$$W=F.x$$


When the magnitude of $$F$$ depends on the value of $$x$$, as is the case here, this expression can be modified slightly:

$$W=\int ^x_0F.dx$$

Which in this case is equal to:

$$W=\int ^x_0k.x.dx=\frac{1}{2}.k.x^2=5 J$$

(Remember to convert from cm to m in all of the above calculations)

questiontext.text:
A force, $$F$$, of 180 N stretches a spring by a distance, $$x$$, of 2.2 cm.




What is the spring constant, $$k$$, in this case?

$$k$$ = {1:NUMERICAL:=-8181.8:-163.6364#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} N/m

How much work would need to be done to stretch this spring by 6 cm, from its unstretched position?

Work = {1:NUMERICAL:=14.7:0.29455#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} J

(Please give your answers correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #34).

generalfeedback.text:
Remember that Hooke's Law states $$F=-k.x$$ for the elastic deformation of a spring:




Therefore:

$$k=-\frac{F}{x}=-8181.8 N/m$$


Work, $$W$$, is defined as the force, $$F$$, applied to a resistance, multiplied by the displacement, $$x$$, of the resistance in the direction of the force:


$$W=F.x$$


When the magnitude of $$F$$ depends on the value of $$x$$, as is the case here, this expression can be modified slightly:

$$W=\int ^x_0F.dx$$

Which in this case is equal to:

$$W=\int ^x_0k.x.dx=\frac{1}{2}.k.x^2=14.7 J$$

(Remember to convert from cm to m in all of the above calculations)

When the magnitude of $$F$$ depends on the value of $$x$$, as is the case here, this expression can be modified slightly:

$$W=\int ^x_0F.dx$$

Which in this case is equal to:

$$W=\int ^x_0k.x.dx=\frac{1}{2}.k.x^2=2.9 J$$

(Remember to convert from cm to m in all of the above calculations)

hint.text:
HINT

Apply Hooke's Law to answer the first part of the question.

Then integrate the force over the distance over which it is applied to answer the second part of the question.

questiontext.text:
A force, $$F$$, of 124 N stretches a spring by a distance, $$x$$, of 1.3 cm.




What is the spring constant, $$k$$, in this case?

$$k$$ = {1:NUMERICAL:=-9538.5:-190.7692#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} N/m

How much work would need to be done to stretch this spring by 7.8 cm, from its unstretched position?

Work = {1:NUMERICAL:=29:0.58032#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} J

(Please give your answers correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #83).

generalfeedback.text:
Remember that Hooke's Law states $$F=-k.x$$ for the elastic deformation of a spring:




Therefore:

$$k=-\frac{F}{x}=-9538.5 N/m$$


Work, $$W$$, is defined as the force, $$F$$, applied to a resistance, multiplied by the displacement, $$x$$, of the resistance in the direction of the force:


$$W=F.x$$


When the magnitude of $$F$$ depends on the value of $$x$$, as is the case here, this expression can be modified slightly:

$$W=\int ^x_0F.dx$$

Which in this case is equal to:

$$W=\int ^x_0k.x.dx=\frac{1}{2}.k.x^2=29 J$$

(Remember to convert from cm to m in all of the above calculations)

Work = {1:NUMERICAL:=13:0.25947#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} J

(Please give your answers correct to 1.d.p.)

(Question ID #99).

generalfeedback.text:
Remember that Hooke's Law states $$F=-k.x$$ for the elastic deformation of a spring:




Therefore:

$$k=-\frac{F}{x}=-6750 N/m$$


Work, $$W$$, is defined as the force, $$F$$, applied to a resistance, multiplied by the displacement, $$x$$, of the resistance in the direction of the force:


$$W=F.x$$


When the magnitude of $$F$$ depends on the value of $$x$$, as is the case here, this expression can be modified slightly:

$$W=\int ^x_0F.dx$$

Which in this case is equal to:

$$W=\int ^x_0k.x.dx=\frac{1}{2}.k.x^2=13 J$$

(Remember to convert from cm to m in all of the above calculations)

Apply Hooke's Law to answer the first part of the question.

Then integrate the force over the distance over which it is applied to answer the second part of the question.
